content.description: Technical face, flaring seams protected by a high crux. Very fun
content.location: On the face of the road facing wall, higher up the trail, but not as far as the Bono Arete.

content.description: This route has a good variety of climbing.  It follows a crack in a dihedral all the way to the chains.  The bottom third is straight forward climbing with a wide chimney to your left that can be stemmed.  The second third involves climbing a hand crack in the dihedral.  While the top third moves into face climbing.  Careful on the decent, the rappel off the chains to the left are a 60m rope stretcher.
content.protection: This route use to be a trad route, but someone bolted it with 12 bolts so climb it trad or sport it's your choice.  Chains on top for rappel.
content.location: The large left facing dihedral at the main parking pullout on the south face of the roadside rock.  Just to the left of Tom Thumb's Blues (Red Roof Inn depending on the guide book you have).

content.description: Starts on "Downtown" but find the first bolt and head straight up. heads right about halfway up towards a nice roof. Hidden holds unlock the roof. Very fun
content.location: Wall facing the road.  USE A 70m to lower from the anchors, or continue climbing past one bolt top to the Washington Pass anchors that can be seen left of climber.

content.description: This route is long and hard. Crux is about 40ft below the top, after a very prominent no-hands rest. Climb up the face mostly on the right hand side, until about 100ft. Then it will move slowly to the left. Hard, thin crux that will make a proud man pucker.
Pull the roof early then head right and up the crack on delicate slab.
content.location: Farthest route right on the south side of Roadside Rock. The roof will be obvious.

content.description: Starts off around 5.7-5.8 and becomes more difficult about half way up. Some tricky moves before the finish, but still solid rock.
content.location: The south end of road side rock just to the left of Carrot Top. Belay from a small mostly slanted ledge.

content.description: Climb up easy slab to a roof below the anchors. Pull the roof and turn right.
Fun climbing up a small dihedral to a bolted crack. Follow the crack up to anchors.
content.location: 200 yards left of Brown Out on the SW side of Roadside Rock

content.description: Start right of Red Roof Inn and head up the large dihedral. Can be done in one long pitch
Climb starts along a ledge system. Head straight up the dihedral along a giant flake system.
content.location: Walk up the ramp system to a large ledge.

content.description: Climb Even Better Than the Real Thing to get to the base of this route. Style past some awesome crimps, incuts and sustained face climbing. Don't miss it!

This route is a favorite of mine in all of Eastern Washington. Fun movement on great holds and features. Well bolted with clean falls. It shares anchors with Red Arete/Bono and it is easy to hang draws from there to project or top rope. This route is not in the LaBelle or Bland guides and from word of mouth I have heard it called Flower Power. If the first ascentionist or local lets me know a different/correct name id be happy to credit them and change the name if needed.

The crux is a long reach from a lock off near the top. There are three good hold options to do this, two of which are on the top of a flake that flexes when fully weighted. It dosen't seem like it will break soon, but if someone yards on it hard outwardly it will eventually. The moves are very possible without the flake, but please be gentle just in case. Perhaps it could be reinforced? Thats up to the first ascentionist and the locals to decide.

All that aside, this is an excellent route and you should climb it
content.protection: Bolts with chains at the top
content.location: Shares anchors with Red Arete/Bono. It is plumb line from the anchors on the face to the right of the arete.

climbs.name: Even Better Than the Real Thing

content.description: This is the easiest way up to the huge ledge which is the base of several other routes. Follow the prominent dihedral using great incuts, edges and sidepulls. If you aren't on a jug, youre off route.
content.protection: Seven bolts to a chain anchor.

content.description: Slab climb to the left of Allergic Reaction. Starts off like a 5.7 but gets more difficult about half way up.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chain anchor and extra bolt on the ledge above.
content.location: Go to the small landing up the hill and to the left of Allergic Reaction on the south end of Roadside Rock. There are two bolted routes on the slab, this is the one on the right.

content.description: Starts with rounded arete, and traverse to the right dihedral.  Fun line up face holds and an arete to climbers right provide airy climbing.
content.location: large ramp looking face on the road side facing walls.

content.description: Climb the slab left of the large crack system along incuts and jugs to a roof. Pull the roof and follow the the gently kicked back face on small edges and a few key rests. Half way you'll find yourself trending left toward the arete. The top slabs out again and travels a lot. Could barley get down with my 70m. One of the best 11's in Washington.
One of the best moderate climbs at Banks Lake. Climb up a protruding and obvious arete just left of Red Rocket.
Climb the slab left of the obvious large crack.
Start in a large offwidth and head left towards the arete.
